articles.headline: Sudans’ Oil Feud Risks Shattering a Fragile Peace
articles.snippet: Sudan and the breakaway nation of South Sudan have been locked in a dangerous game of brinkmanship over billions of gallons of oil.
articles.abstract: Sudan and the breakaway nation of South Sudan have been locked in a dangerous game of brinkmanship over billions of gallons of oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Sudan and the breakaway nation of South Sudan have been locked in an exceedingly dangerous game of brinkmanship over billions of gallons of oil, seizing tankers, shutting down wells and imperiling the tenuous, American-backed peace that has held — just barely — between the two countries after decades of war.

articles.headline: When Cars Meet Politics, a Clash
articles.snippet: The combination of a strong jobs report and an inspirational Chrysler commercial at the Super Bowl seems to have touched some raw nerves.
articles.abstract: The combination of a strong jobs report and an inspirational Chrysler commercial at the Super Bowl seems to have touched some raw nerves.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Good morning to you all,” Chrysler’s chief executive, Sergio Marchionne, began as he made a surprise appearance last Sunday morning before 700 Chrysler dealers at the annual meeting of the National Automobile Dealers Association. “Although it wasn’t planned, I decided to stay overnight here in Las Vegas to greet you personally.”

articles.headline: At an Airline That Caters to Pets, the Humans Are Howling
articles.snippet: Pet Airways, once the great transportation hope for animal owners, is low on cash and has been canceling flights.
articles.abstract: Pet Airways, once the great transportation hope for animal owners, is low on cash and has been canceling flights.
articles.lead_paragraph: An airline just for pets was an act of genius, Martha Hamilton figured. No cold cargo holds for Phoebe, her 10-year-old miniature schnauzer. Attendants would check on her regularly during the flight. There would even be a pet lounge for the emotional goodbye at the airport.

articles.headline: Obama Budget Bets Other Concerns Will Trump the Deficit
articles.snippet: President Obama’s budget blueprint, to be laid out Monday, is an election-year wager that higher taxes on the rich and spending on popular programs will outweigh deficit concerns.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s budget blueprint, to be laid out Monday, is an election-year wager that higher taxes on the rich and spending on popular programs will outweigh deficit concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will lay out a budget blueprint on Monday that amounts to an election-year bet that a plan for higher taxes on the rich and more spending on popular programs like infrastructure and manufacturing will trump concerns over the deficit.

articles.headline: A Confused Nuclear Cleanup
articles.snippet: Some of the companies that built Japan’s nuclear plants are now cashing in on the cleanup, though their knowledge of decontamination is a work in progress.
articles.abstract: Some of the companies that built Japan’s nuclear plants are now cashing in on the cleanup, though their knowledge of decontamination is a work in progress.
articles.lead_paragraph: IITATE, Japan — As 500 workers in hazmat suits and respirator masks fanned out to decontaminate this village 20 miles from the ravaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear reactors, their confusion was apparent.

articles.headline: Traveling Light in a Time of Digital Thievery
articles.snippet: Information has become easier to steal over the Internet because employees can carry proprietary data around.
articles.abstract: Information has become easier to steal over the Internet because employees can carry proprietary data around.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Kenneth G. Lieberthal, a China expert at the Brookings Institution, travels to that country, he follows a routine that seems straight from a spy film.

articles.headline: Car Dealers Wince at a Site to End Sales Haggling
articles.snippet: TrueCar.com promises to deliver a guaranteed price for a car, efforts that automakers have pushed back against, saying that they could eat into already thin profit margins.
articles.abstract: TrueCar.com promises to deliver a guaranteed price for a car, efforts that automakers have pushed back against, saying that they could eat into already thin profit margins.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to negotiating a price on a new car, the script has not really changed much over the years: The dealer’s salesman writes down a price, you counter and then he walks to the back of the showroom to talk with the manager to “see what we can do.”

articles.headline: A Newspaper, and a Legacy, Reordered
articles.snippet: The Washington Post, shrinking its scope as it looks to a digital future, is undergoing one of the most sweeping reorientations of any newspaper in the country.
articles.abstract: The Washington Post, shrinking its scope as it looks to a digital future, is undergoing one of the most sweeping reorientations of any newspaper in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON

articles.headline: Hacking Cases Focus on Memo to a Murdoch
articles.snippet: Discovered just three months ago, an e-mail from June 2008 sent to James Murdoch discussed in frank terms the potentially disastrous scale of phone hacking at News International.
articles.abstract: Discovered just three months ago, an e-mail from June 2008 sent to James Murdoch discussed in frank terms the potentially disastrous scale of phone hacking at News International.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As dozens of investigators and high-powered lawyers converge on Rupert Murdoch’s News International in the phone hacking scandal, attention has focused on the printout of an e-mail excavated three months ago from a sealed carton left behind in an empty company office.
articles.byline: By Sarah Lyall and Ravi Somaiya

articles.headline: The Deal Is Done, but Hold the Applause
articles.snippet: The settlement reached last week over questionable mortgage practices by major American banks hardly cracks the iceberg that is the foreclosure mess.
articles.abstract: The settlement reached last week over questionable mortgage practices by major American banks hardly cracks the iceberg that is the foreclosure mess.
articles.lead_paragraph: FIVE big banks finally reached a deal with government authorities last week over dubious mortgage practices and foreclosure abuses.

articles.headline: It’s the Economy, Honey
articles.snippet: Betsey Stevenson and Justin Wolfers form a sort of power couple in economics. They’re the go-to pair on financial issues of marriage, divorce and child-rearing.
articles.abstract: Betsey Stevenson and Justin Wolfers form a sort of power couple in economics. They’re the go-to pair on financial issues of marriage, divorce and child-rearing.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA

articles.headline: Romney’s Path to ‘Pro-Life’ Position on Abortion
articles.snippet: After supporting abortion rights early in his political career, Mitt Romney is working to reinforce his credentials among conservatives.
articles.abstract: After supporting abortion rights early in his political career, Mitt Romney is working to reinforce his credentials among conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From the moment he left business for politics, the issue of abortion has bedeviled Mitt Romney.

articles.headline: Risks of Afghan War Shift From Soldiers to Contractors
articles.snippet: More civilian contractors working for American companies than American soldiers died in Afghanistan last year for the first time, and some survivors are left uncompensated.
articles.abstract: More civilian contractors working for American companies than American soldiers died in Afghanistan last year for the first time, and some survivors are left uncompensated.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Even dying is being outsourced here.

articles.headline: Even Critics of Safety Net Increasingly Depend on It
articles.snippet: The government safety net was created to keep Americans from abject poverty, but the poorest households no longer receive a majority of government benefits.
articles.abstract: The government safety net was created to keep Americans from abject poverty, but the poorest households no longer receive a majority of government benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: LINDSTROM, Minn. — Ki Gulbranson owns a logo apparel shop, deals in jewelry on the side and referees youth soccer games. He makes about $39,000 a year and wants you to know that he does not need any help from the federal government.
articles.byline: By Binyamin Appelbaum and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Economists Warn of Long-Term Perils in Rescue of Europe’s Banks
articles.snippet: Because of the central bank’s cheap financing, some economists warn, sick banks now face less pressure to confront their problems, which could worsen in the years ahead.
articles.abstract: Because of the central bank’s cheap financing, some economists warn, sick banks now face less pressure to confront their problems, which could worsen in the years ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Few would begrudge Mario Draghi his boast last week that he and the European Central Bank had prevented a disastrous credit crisis by showering banks with cheap loans in December.

articles.headline: Greek Parliament Passes Austerity Plan After Riots Rage
articles.snippet: As demonstrators torched shops and battled police in the streets of Athens, lawmakers approved a tough austerity package that is expected to help the country avoid default.
articles.abstract: As demonstrators torched shops and battled police in the streets of Athens, lawmakers approved a tough austerity package that is expected to help the country avoid default.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — After violent protests left dozens of buildings aflame in Athens, the Greek Parliament voted early on Monday to approve a package of harsh austerity measures demanded by the country’s foreign lenders in exchange for new loans to keep Greece from defaulting on its debt.
articles.byline: By Niki Kitsantonis and Rachel Donadio

articles.headline: In Amanda Knox Tale, a Delicate Bet for Publishers
articles.snippet: Will the story of an American student’s exoneration in the killing of her roommate abroad appeal to readers?
articles.abstract: Will the story of an American student’s exoneration in the killing of her roommate abroad appeal to readers?
articles.lead_paragraph: In person, Amanda Knox came across as soft-spoken, smart, almost scholarly, naming literary novels that she found moving. She said it was a longtime dream of hers to be a writer. And her book, she told the publishers, editors and publicists who listened raptly, would be the true and unvarnished story of what happened in Perugia, Italy.

articles.headline: Erasing the Boundaries
articles.snippet: The new strategy for technology companies is to build a device, sell it to consumers and then sell them the content to play on it — and maybe some ads too.
articles.abstract: The new strategy for technology companies is to build a device, sell it to consumers and then sell them the content to play on it — and maybe some ads too.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Technology used to be so simple.

articles.headline: Twitter Is All in Good Fun, Until It Isn’t
articles.snippet: Especially for companies that encourage its use, Twitter creates an ongoing tension between boss and employee as Roland Martin of CNN recently discovered.
articles.abstract: Especially for companies that encourage its use, Twitter creates an ongoing tension between boss and employee as Roland Martin of CNN recently discovered.
articles.lead_paragraph: I was going to tweet about Roland Martin’s suspension from CNN, but I decided to write a column about it instead. It’s safer this way.

articles.headline: At MSNBC, a Professor as TV Host
articles.snippet: Melissa Harris-Perry, with her progressive talk show of the same name, is set to join MSNBC’s weekend lineup of cable news shows beginning Saturday.
articles.abstract: Melissa Harris-Perry, with her progressive talk show of the same name, is set to join MSNBC’s weekend lineup of cable news shows beginning Saturday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Week seven of Melissa Harris-Perry’s introductory course in African-American studies at Tulane University includes a lecture about “the hollow prize” — a theory that African-Americans tend to be elected as mayor only after a city has tipped into economic decline.

articles.headline: For Iraqis, Aid to Rebels in Syria Repays a Debt
articles.snippet: Syrians sent money and weapons to Iraq and accepted its refugees just a few years ago; now Iraqis hope to return the favor.
articles.abstract: Syrians sent money and weapons to Iraq and accepted its refugees just a few years ago; now Iraqis hope to return the favor.
articles.lead_paragraph: FALLUJA, Iraq — Not so long ago, Syrians worked to send weapons and fighters into Iraq to help Sunnis fighting a sectarian conflict; suddenly, it is the other way around.
articles.byline: By TIM ARANGO and DURAID ADNAN

articles.headline: Admiral Seeks Freer Hand in Deployment of Elite Forces
articles.snippet: Adm. William H. McRaven, who leads the Special Operations Command, is seeking new authority to move his forces more quickly and outside normal deployment channels.
articles.abstract: Adm. William H. McRaven, who leads the Special Operations Command, is seeking new authority to move his forces more quickly and outside normal deployment channels.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the United States turns increasingly to Special Operations forces to confront developing threats scattered around the world, the nation’s top Special Operations officer, a member of the Navy Seals who oversaw the raid that killed Osama bin Laden, is seeking new authority to move his forces faster and outside of normal Pentagon deployment channels.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Mark Mazzetti and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Romney Runs as an Outsider but Makes Room for Lobbyists
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney is running against the entrenched interests of Washington with help from some of its most prominent insiders.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney is running against the entrenched interests of Washington with help from some of its most prominent insiders.
articles.lead_paragraph: They have hosted fund-raisers and raised millions of dollars for his campaign. They employed some of his top operatives after his first White House run, helped create the platform for his second bid and have deployed regularly to attack his Republican rivals on the campaign trail.

articles.headline: Israel Says Iran Is Behind Bombs
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu blamed Iran for the bombs on Monday aimed at Israeli Embassy personnel in New Delhi and Tbilisi, the capital of Georgia.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu blamed Iran for the bombs on Monday aimed at Israeli Embassy personnel in New Delhi and Tbilisi, the capital of Georgia.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Tensions between Israel and Iran rose sharply on Monday when bombers struck at Israeli Embassy personnel in the capitals of India and Georgia. Israel accused the Tehran government of being behind the attacks, which Iran denied.
